name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text:

No, the filibuster is not in the Constitution.

No, the filibuster has not existed since the creation of the Senate.

No, the filibuster does not foster bipartisanship when it‚Äôs abused to cheat our democratic system.

These are our values. 

This is why we fight.
¬†
This is how we #BuildBackBetter ‚Äî not only for the rich and well-connected, but for every single American.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: We value our environment, and are using reconciliation to make the single largest investment in the fight against climate change in history.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: We value the health and wellbeing of the American people, and are using reconciliation to expand access to vital health services (particularly for seniors) and to lower the cost of care across the board.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: We value American children and their parents, and are using reconciliation to drastically lower child care costs and provide access to preschool for every kid.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: We value working Americans, and are using reconciliation to cut their taxes‚Äînot the super-rich.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text:
Republicans have stated their values loudly and clearly. 

But here are the values that @POTUS and @HouseDemocrats fighting for.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text:
When Republicans last used the budget reconciliation process, it was to pass a $2 trillion tax cut for corporations and the ultra-wealthy.
¬†
Before that, they used it to rip health care away from more than 20 million Americans.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text:
When I served in local government, I helped to write and pass 14 consecutive budgets.

If I learned one thing from that process, it‚Äôs that budgets truly are statements of values.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text:
There‚Äôs no question that Donald J. Trump lit this flame. 

But, as we reflect on that wretched day six months later,  never forget that it was Republicans in Congress who handed him the match.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text:
With our own eyes, we saw Trump whip a crowd of his supporters into a frenzy and urge them to march to the Capitol. With our own ears, we heard Rudy Giuliani tell them to engage in a "trial by combat." 

The mob was given orders, and the world watched as they carried them out.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: I will not mince words about that nightmare. The siege of the US Capitol was an act of violent insurrection against a coequal branch of the federal government, incited by a president desperate for power and incapable of coping with perceived humiliation or defeat.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: Tragically, a rioter pushing her way through that same broken window was shot and killed several moments later.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: As we left for a secure location through the Speaker's Lobby, I turned and saw another makeshift barricade had been erected. I looked up and through smashed glass saw a second faction of the mob attempting to force their way onto the floor from the front of the Chamber.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: We were evacuated from the Chamber as the mob smashed through the windows and attempted to break down the doors at the main entrance to the floor -- the same doors presidents are ushered through to deliver State of the Union addresses.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: Speaker Pelosi and others were rushed off the floor while the Sergeant at Arms locked the chamber doors and instructed members to don the gas masks kept under our seats in case of a chemical attack. With weapons drawn, Capitol Police used furniture to barricade the doors.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: On Wednesday, January 6 I arrived at the Capitol for the counting of the Electoral College votes. I was on the House floor when the building was breached and the House Chamber was placed into lockdown.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text:
Congress must act. We have legislation ready now, and we have more on the way.

This is a rare moment of stark right and wrong. I urge @senatemajldr McConnell, and all my Republican colleagues, to think long and hard before choosing a side.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: 8. @RepRoKhanna's PEACE Act, which would change the use of force standard for federal officers to require that force must be necessary, as a last resort, to prevent imminent death or serious bodily injury.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: 7. @RepJasonCrow's Law Enforcement Trust and Integrity Act, which provides incentives for local police departments to voluntarily adopt performance-based standards to minimize incidents of misconduct, improve operations and enhance community accountability.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: 6. @RepGwenMoore's Preventing Tragedies Between Police and Communities Act requires a state or local government that receives funding under the JAG program to train law enforcement officers on de-escalation techniques and require law enforcement to use such techniques.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: 5. And his Police Training and Independent Review Act, which authorizes the DOJ to award grants to States that require law enforcement officers to be trained on ethics and racial bias, cultural diversity, and police interaction with the disabled, mentally ill, and new immigrants.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: 4. @RepCohen's National Statistics on Deadly Force Transparency Act, which would require federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies to collect and publish data on the use of deadly force by law enforcement officers.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: 3. @RepJeffries' Eric Garner Excessive Use of Force Prevention Act, which makes the use of chokeholds by law enforcement unlawful through an amendment to civil rights statute.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: 2. @JacksonLeeTX18's End Racial Profiling Act, which prohibits federal, state, and local law enforcement from racial profiling.

name: Rep. Gerry Connolly
tweet_text: 1. @RepHankJohnson's Stop Militarizing Law Enforcement Act, which would end the transfers of certain military equipment to local law enforcement. In 2017 President Trump fully restored DOD's program that transferred more than $6 billion in military equipment to our streets.
